Miles Sound System SDK 6.1c

AIL_init_sample

The function AIL_init_sample prepares a sample handle for playback of audio data.

void AIL_init_sample(
  HSAMPLE S
);

In Parameters

S
indicates the sample handle to prepare for audio playback.

Discussion

This function initializes all parameters associated with a sample handle to a set of nominal values. It must be called immediately after allocating a sample handle with AIL_allocate_sample_handle, as well as anytime an existing sample handle is used to play a new audio data sample.

AIL_init_sample initializes the sample's playback information as follows:

The sample's status is set to SMP_DONE.

The starting addresses of both the primary and secondary sample buffers are set to NULL, and their lengths are set to 0. Consequently, normal single-buffer playback is enabled.

The sample's position counter is set to 0 (start-of-sample).

The sample's loop counter is set to 1 (no looping).

The sample format is initialized to 11025 Hz, monaural 8-bit unsigned PCM data.

The sample's volume value is set to the DIG_DEFAULT_VOLUME preference. The default value for DIG_DEFAULT_VOLUME is 100 on a scale of 0 to 127. The slightly reduced default volume value helps to bridge the inherent volume imbalance between FM music and digital audio on many sound cards.

The sample's panpot value is set to 64 (dead center) on a scale of 0 (hard left) to 127 (hard right).

The start-of-block, end-of-buffer, and end-of-sample callbacks are all canceled.

Since AIL_init_sample resets parameters such as volume, pan location, loop count, and other playback characteristics, it should appear before any calls to functions such as AIL_set_sample_volume or AIL_set_sample_loop_count, or these functions will have no effect. Of course, only values which the application wishes to change from their defaults need to be set prior to calling AIL_start_sample. For example, if the application does not require an off-center panpot value for the sample, it is not necessary to call AIL_set_sample_pan(S,64) to initialize the panpot control.

None of the digital audio library functions alter or modify application sample data in any way. The same sample data may safely be passed to other drivers (or even used more than once per driver) without being reloaded into memory.

Example files that use this function: SSTEST.C
